J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> Chad Woolley wrote:
> 
> 
>>> This is a situation where Aspect-Oriented Programming might be useful
>>> after all.
>>> 
> 
> <snip />
> 
>>> AOP could be well suited for this type of task, because otherwise you
>>> would have to duplicate this monitoring code (or at least remember to
>>> duplicate a call to it) in each test method.
> 
> 
> What if you just extended TestCase and made all your tests extend that 
> new implementation? Would that work? Isn't that how JUnitPerf works?


Yes.  However, my note was saying that the framework-extension approach may not 
(easily) work in some cases.  For example, if your fixture-setup in your 
TestCases took much longer, relatively, than the actual execution time of the 
Class Under Test.  This could cause (relatively) slight variances in the 
fixture-setup times to obscure (relatively) large variances in the excution time 
of your Class Under Test.

In this case, wrapping the performance metrics around the entire test method 
invocation may not be good enough.  You may need to wrap your performance 
metrics at a much finer granularity - such as directly around the invocation to 
the Class Under Test.

This is most likely possible with a Plain Java approach, but I think it would be 
kind of tricky, and most likely involve reflection and the requirement to wrap 
all calls to your Classes Under Test to pass them through the metrics-gathering 
code.

AOP could provide a more elegant solution to this problem.  Each testcase could 
define it's Class Under Test in an instance variable.  The Aspect could then 
automatically detect and wrap all these calls with the metrics-gathering code. 
In this case, there is no need to remember to wrap every call to the Class Under 
Test, or to deal with the clutter and obscurity that would add.  Just a simple 
instance method and some code in a single aspect.

Of course, if you have all your fixtures perfectly refactored, and only have One 
  Assertion Per Test with no fixure code in the test method, that could change 
everything.  Not everyone has that situation, though ;)

Thanks,
Chad
